subanswer.text: The inequality describes a triangle bounded by lines at angles (i) $y=0$; (ii) $x=0$; (iii) $x+y=4$. Therefore, its vertices have coordinates $(\mathrm{O},~\mathrm{O})$, where $\mathrm{O}$ denotes origin; $(4,~0)$, and $(0,~4)$. The area of the rectangle $[0,8]\times [0,4]$ equals $|\mathbb R|$: $|ABCD|=16$, which means that any part of said rectangle could match our requirements under independence assumptions about how randomness works here. Thus $$P(\text {the }p\text{-area}) =\dfrac {|\triangle OA'D|}{|\mathbb R|}=\dfrac{|OB||OD|}{|\mathbb R|}$$ Note also that because $B$ lies entirely below line segment $AC$, so too must lie every other dot inside square ABCD -- implying equality between areas! And since triangles share bases parallelly aligned across horizontal planes , their height ratios should hold constant throughout space . Hence $$\dfrac {PA'} P_B = |\triangle COD|$$ In particular,\[\begin{aligned}\dfrac {\overline{(OP)}} {\overline{(OP')}} &= \dfrac{\overline{[OC]} [\overline{[COD]}]}{\overline{[OC]} [\overline{OB}\,+\, \overline{OD}]}\\ &=\dfrac{\overline{[BO\,+\, AD]}}{\overline{[OB}\,+\, AD]} \\&=1\end{aligned}$$ Finally substituting values yields \[\dfrac{\bar AB\,\,\,[\quad (\bar BC +\quad)\quad ]}{\;\;(\bar BM +\quad)\, \, \quad}\,\,\,[\quad\, (c)]\;:\;\;\\&=\dfrac{16}{16}\\=1\] So overall probabilty becomes equalized against certain events occurring via uniform distribution theory applied along axes perpendicularity principles !!!
